website_summaries.verdict: Intel Core i7 processing and AMD Vega graphics power meet in the Intel NUC Kit NUC8i7HVK, a super-slim bare-bones desktop that packs punchy, VR-ready performance and extraordinary connectivity.
pros: Excellent overall CPU and GPU performance
Bristling with connectivity for its size
cons: Steep price, once you factor in all components

customer_reviews.title: Great for developmnet
customer_reviews.text: This Intel PC is a beast. With 32GB ram and EVO sumsung SSD if lightening fast!!! Great for developmnet.
customer_reviews.author: Alexander Xanthoudakis

customer_reviews.title: Great peice of harware
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic! If you know what you buy it for. This device is great for running muntiple virtual OSs to create testing evironment. I have read a lot of review and most of them are about games... If you want to play games, why not buy those montrous game descktops or a gaming laptop?
customer_reviews.author: Di

customer_reviews.title: I've never had so much power at home. And ...
customer_reviews.text: I've never had so much power at home. And it's so small. It comes a little bit noisy but you can tune it.
customer_reviews.author: T. Wibberley

customer_reviews.title: random reboots
customer_reviews.text: this nuc randomely reboots depite all bios, driver, firmware being up to date. Trying to solve the issue (that does not seem an isolated case) with Intel. In case the issue is not solved, I will return it
customer_reviews.author: Battt

customer_reviews.title: Powerhouse
customer_reviews.text: Incredible power in a tiny form factor. Slightly outdated components- but still works well.
customer_reviews.author: Josh LL

customer_reviews.title: Good.
customer_reviews.text: Good product, good build quality. Little bit on the loud side for my liking.
customer_reviews.author: Jose

customer_reviews.title: Perfect
customer_reviews.text: If you are looking for an ESXi lab it work great. I won't recommend it for Gaming.
customer_reviews.author: Ludo

customer_reviews.title: Good CPU machine
customer_reviews.text: good and powerful little beast, but too expensive to perform any modifications.
customer_reviews.author: Kirill

customer_reviews.title: NUC6i7KYK is effortless power
customer_reviews.text: Arrived speedily. I fitted it with 2 x Samsung 950 Pro 512Gb and Kingston HyperX 32Gb RAM. The hardware was fitted in seconds. I downloaded W10 PRO direct to USB from the Microsoft download site.I also copied the Intel network drivers to the same USB stick. Installation was a no BIOS affair. However, I did need the already downloaded network drivers to to get the Windows update process started. The NUC6i7KYK links to my LG 4k TV by HDMI cable and effortlessly outputs the full 4k while also extending to the ASUS monitor in 2k using DP cable.
customer_reviews.author: TooFar

customer_reviews.title: ... DevOps engineer I use this product for some serious fun. ESXI 6
customer_reviews.text: As an aspiring data scientist and a DevOps engineer I use this product for some serious fun. ESXI 6.x compatibility is not full (audio and WiFi will not work) but depends on your plan. With proper M2 SSD and 32GB of RAM this machine can run your home lab without any problem.
customer_reviews.author: Szabolcs Szallar

customer_reviews.title: NUC6i7KYK versions
customer_reviews.text: Having seen three different versions of this NUC on Amazon or NUC6i7KYK, NUC6i7KYK2 and NUC6i7KYK3 I decided to investigate the differences. Conclusion: The different codes result in different power leads. NUC6i7KYK3 is a UK power lead. NUC6i7KYK2 is an EU version whilst NUC6i7KYK has no power lead. Hope this helps.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

product_meta.title: Intel BOXNUC6i7KYK3 i7-6770HQ NUC Kit - Metallic
product_meta.description:
NUC Kit NUC6i7KYK,The typical NUC was a 4- or 5-inch square, and ultimately Intel was able to get Core i5 and i7 mobile-grade CPUs into the tiny confines of these machines. Beyond the NUC, Intel took things to another level of small with the 2015 Compute Stick That's what Intel has done with its new-for-2016 flagship NUC Kit. Code-named the much catchier "Skull Canyon" in the run-up to its launch, the NUC Kit NUC6i7KYK takes the form factor of the typical Intel NUC and runs a steamroller over it, widening and flattening the body to allow for more-potent component possibilities inside. "Skylake" 6th-Generation processors are the order of the day—there was a whopper in our $650 review unit—and Intel also foregoes 2.5-inch hard drives and solid-state drives (SSDs) altogether, instead opting for a pair of slots for gum stick-size M.2 SSDs to save space,NUCs are astounding for the technology they pack into their small bodies, but to date they have admittedly looked bland. Intel did allow for some of its last-generation NUCs to be bulk-ordered with custom corporate or other logos on top, but this is the first NUC that comes out of the box with a real sense of attitude. Intel's enthusiast-minded skull logo takes up half the lid, and the overall shape is sportier than any NUC before,On the whole, the "Skull Canyon" NUC kit is the state of the art in mini-PCs that rely on integrated graphics. It's not cheap—once you factor in the parts you need to get our review unit up and running, there's likely a $1,000 hole in your credit card, in total. But if you're looking for the rare mini-PC that can accept video cards and video-card upgrades without being big enough to house one, it's worth serious consideration, thanks to its Thunderbolt 3 port and its support for emerging external-graphics-card solutions. Indeed, this NUC has been demonstrated in recent months working with Razer's new Core external-graphics box.

BOX CONTAINS
1 x NUC/BOXNUC6i7KYK3 i7-6770HQ UK
